channel.title: Master Feed (Updated every 30 mins)
channel.description: Master Feed (Updated every 30 mins) generated by script

item.title: UN Report Warns of Escalating Human Rights Abuses Against Migrants and Refugees in Libya
item.description: A new UN report warns of the “brutal and normalized reality” for migrants, refugees and asylum seekers in Libya as they face exploitation and human rights violations. On February 18, the Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights (OHCHR) and the United Nations Support Mission in Libya (UNSMIL) released a joint report […]

item.title: Devex Career Hub: 3 new rules for landing globaldev roles
item.description: This week: Expert tips for how to get unstuck in your 2026 job search; who's hiring the most in Switzerland; featured new job leads; and more.

item.title: US senator: ‘Much more money than you would think’ in US development
item.description: Democratic Sen. Chris Coons spoke to Devex in the hallways of the Munich Security Conference.

item.title: World Bank chief's role on Trump-led Board of Peace prompts questions
item.description: Does President Ajay Banga's participation on the board blur the bank's neutrality, or is it a smart move?

item.title: Should the defense spending ramp-up also tackle climate change?
item.description: As defense leaders prioritize tanks and ammunition, front-line nations warn that ignoring climate change as a risk multiplier is a costly strategic failure.

item.title: The top global development employers in Sudan
item.description: This article highlights the development organizations that recruited the most staff in 2025 amid the ongoing civil war in Sudan.

item.title: German development agency head: Cuts 'will haunt us in the future'
item.description: GIZ’s Ingrid-Gabriela Hoven says shrinking development budgets could ultimately make the world less secure.

item.title: Devex Newswire: US State Department plans new disaster response bureau
item.description: The proposed Bureau of Disaster and Humanitarian Response will separate international relief from politically charged migration programs at the State Department. Plus, CEPI’s $2.5 billion ask, and lessons from Munich and Addis Ababa.

item.title: ‘Alarming increase’ in recruitment of children into gangs in Haiti
item.description: There has been an “alarming increase” in the number of children being recruited into gangs in Haiti with “devastating consequences” for children, families and society as a whole, the UN reported on Friday.

item.title: Ukraine’s women at breaking point after four years of war as attacks on energy, healthcare continue – UN humanitarians
item.description: Four years into Russia’s full-scale invasion, millions in Ukraine struggle to keep the lights on and heat their homes, with the crisis taking a particular toll on women, humanitarians warned on Friday.

item.title: Ode to U.S. Civil Rights Icon Rev. Jesse Jackson Sr: A Life That Carried the Rainbow
item.description: When the Rev. Jesse Jackson Sr. declared, “Keep hope alive,” it was not a slogan. It was a discipline. It was a moral posture. It was a promise to those America had locked out of its prosperity and pushed to the margins of its democracy. And for more than five decades, Jackson kept that promise […]

item.title: Players Score Dignity in India’s First Transgender Football League
item.description: Pyari Hessa, 26, balances long shifts as a loco traffic controller at a steel company in Jamshedpur with evening football practice on the same turf where professionals train. A trans woman from the Ho tribal community, she was born Pyare Lal in Bedamundui, a remote village 50 kilometres away from Chaibasa, the headquarters town of […]

item.title: What we learned at the African Union Summit and Munich Security Conference
item.description: For the latest episode of our weekly podcast series, Senior Reporter Adva Saldinger sits down with reporters Ayenat Mersie and Jesse Chase-Lubitz to look back at the African Union Summit and the Munich Security Conference.

item.title: Why Ending Child Marriage is Key to Advancing Africa’s Economic Development
item.description: Africa is home to approximately 160 million adolescent girls aged 10 to 19 (according to 2022 data by the United Nations Population Division). They embody the energy, creativity, and potential of the continent. It is undeniable that The Africa We Want, as envisioned in the African Union’s Agenda 2063, will not be realized without the […]

item.title: Exclusive: US State Department proposes humanitarian overhaul
item.description: The Trump administration is planning a major overhaul of the State Department's international disaster response system, proposing a new Bureau of Disaster and Humanitarian Response to separate international relief from politically charged migration programs.

item.title: Devex CheckUp: The cost of falling out of favor with Washington
item.description: One year after U.S. foreign aid cuts, South Africa’s public health system is struggling to pick up the pieces. Plus, aid cuts put gains against female genital mutilation at risk, and cholera prevention campaigns resume.

item.title: Former UNGA president calls for the overhaul of UN leadership
item.description: As the U.N. marks 80 years, María Fernanda Espinosa calls for “networked multilateralism” and a female secretary-general to adapt the institution for the challenges of the 21st century.

item.title: The green skills gap isn’t about money. It’s about delivery
item.description: Opinion: Climate financing projects must consider not only infrastructure but also education and workforce systems in order to achieve a green economy.

item.title: Devex Newswire: Mutilated but not abandoned. Will aid cuts change that?
item.description: Devex traveled to Kenya’s Narok County to bring firsthand details of the impact of female genital mutilation and the implications of foreign aid cuts on grassroots efforts to rescue survivors. Plus, critical minerals in the spotlight at the AU summit.

item.title: Security Council LIVE: Sudan in focus amid genocide warnings in Darfur
item.description: The UN Security Council meets this morning to discuss Sudan as the war nears its third year and fighting intensifying across multiple regions and civilians facing deepening humanitarian catastrophe. Senior UN political and humanitarian officials are expected to brief ministers on a conflict marked by shifting front lines, advanced weaponry and widespread displacement. The meeting comes amid fresh warnings that atrocities in Darfur, including acts bearing the “hallmarks of genocide” in El-Fasher, signal a dangerous escalation. Follow the live coverage below, UN News App users click here.

item.title: Fears of ethnic cleansing in Gaza and the West Bank: UN rights report
item.description: Increased Israeli attacks and the forced transfer of Palestinians have sparked concern over ethnic cleansing in the Gaza Strip and the West Bank, the UN human rights office, OHCHR, said in a report issued on Thursday.

item.title: Sudan: ‘Hallmarks of genocide’ found in El Fasher, UN investigators detail mass killings and ethnic targeting
item.description: The Rapid Support Forces (RSF) carried out ethnically targeted killings, widespread sexual violence and enforced disappearances during their late-October takeover of El Fasher in Sudan’s Darfur region — acts that a UN fact-finding mission said show “hallmarks of genocide” against the Zaghawa and Fur communities and signal an ongoing risk of further atrocities.

item.title: UN rights chief: AI must be based on inclusivity, accountability and global standards
item.description: The UN High Commissioner for Human Rights, Volker Türk, has warned that without urgent guardrails, AI risks deepening inequality, amplifying bias and fuelling real-world harm.

item.title: ‘No corner of Sudan is safe’: UN officials warn of famine and atrocities as war intensifies
item.description: Nearly three years into Sudan’s war, violence is intensifying, famine conditions are looming in parts of the country, and civilians remain trapped between shifting front lines, senior UN political and humanitarian officials told the Security Council on Thursday, warning that the risk of further mass atrocities remains alarmingly high.

item.title: World News in Brief: Conflict deepens hunger crisis in South Sudan, restrictions hinder aid delivery in Gaza, UN child rights envoy concludes first visit to Syria
item.description: The UN World Food Programme (WFP) is scaling up its emergency response in South Sudan’s Jonglei state, where escalating conflict has displaced hundreds of thousands of people and pushed hunger to critical levels.

item.title: UNICEF calls for release of children detained during Iran protests
item.description: The UN Children’s Fund (UNICEF) has called for the immediate release of all children detained during the recent public unrest in Iran, expressing deep concern that minors arrested in connection with the protests remain behind bars.

item.title: ‘Worrying’ War on Drugs Rhetoric Comes with Human, Financial Costs
item.description: Drug reform campaigners have called for an overhaul of global drug controls amid an increasingly complex and deadly drug situation in the world and as hardline anti-drug approaches are increasingly being used as cover for repression of civil society and human rights defenders. A report released earlier this month by the International Drug Policy Consortium […]

item.title: Turning the Tide: How West Africa Is Reasserting Its Food Sovereignty Through Aquaculture
item.description: It is an indictment on the global food system that, despite having some of the richest and most endowed natural resources in the world and a burgeoning youth population, West Africa spends more than $2 billion a year importing aquatic foods to feed its people, almost half of which is spent by Côte d’Ivoire alone. […]

item.title: UN Security Council Meets on Gaza, the Day Before Trump’s Board of Peace Convenes
item.description: The United Nations Security Council, like the rest of the world, will be watching the inaugural meeting on Feb. 19 of President Trump’s Board of Peace, the new entity established by a Council resolution to implement the US-led 20-point peace plan to end the two-year war between Israel and Hamas. The Council met on Feb. ... Read more

item.title: Devex Dish: The food lowdown from the AU Summit
item.description: At the African Union Summit and the Munich Security Conference, food systems leaders make the investment case underlining why food security equals global security. Plus, goodbye to the EAT Foundation.

item.title: Devex Newswire: Taiwan bets on NGOs to boost global clout
item.description: Taipei is planning to establish an international NGO hub to counter pressure from China and strengthen its international relationships. Plus, California, New York, and Illinois are partnering with the World Health Organization.

item.title: UN Libya envoy warns Security Council political deadlock threatens state unity
item.description: Libya’s prolonged political stalemate, worsening economic conditions and an emerging split within the judiciary pose mounting risks to the country’s unity, the UN’s top envoy for the country, Hanna Serwaa Tetteh, told the Security Council on Tuesday.

item.title: Artists face steep income decline due to AI, UNESCO finds
item.description: Creators worldwide are facing mounting financial pressures as rapid advances in digital technologies and artificial intelligence continue to transform the cultural and creative industries, according to a new global report released by the UN culture agency, UNESCO, on Wednesday.

item.title: Sudan: Rights chief alarmed after at least 57 killed in drone attacks in two days
item.description: The UN High Commissioner for Human Rights called on Wednesday for warring parties in Sudan to take urgent steps to protect civilians after at least 57 people were killed in separate drone strikes over two days this week.

item.title: From India, Guterres calls for $3 billion fund to ensure AI benefits all
item.description: The future of Artificial Intelligence “cannot be decided by a handful of countries or left to the whims of a few billionaires,” the UN Secretary-General told the AI Impact Summit in New Delhi on Thursday, calling for a Global Fund to help developing nations to better access these technologies.

item.title: World News in Brief: Guterres calls for fair swtich to clean energy, Ramadan in Gaza, violence and displacement escalate in South Sudan
item.description: The world has “entered the age of clean energy” and renewables are now the cheapest, fastest and safest source of new electricity almost everywhere, UN Secretary-General António Guterres said in a video message to the International Energy Agency ministerial meeting in Paris on Wednesday.

item.title: Security Council LIVE: Situation in the Middle East
item.description: The UN Security Council meets at 3 PM (New York time) on Wednesday to discuss the situation in the Middle East, with rising tensions in the occupied West Bank expected to dominate the session. Under-Secretary-General for Political Affairs Rosemary DiCarlo is scheduled to brief members. The meeting follows recent Israeli cabinet decisions expanding control in Areas A, B and C of the West Bank. Secretary-General António Guterres has warned that the current trajectory is “eroding the prospect” of a two-State solution. Follow the live coverage below, UN News App users click here.

item.title: Decades of gains overshadowed as Asia-Pacific falls behind on sustainable development targets
item.description: Climate inaction, biodiversity loss and rising emissions are pushing Asia and the Pacific further off course on the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), with the region set to miss nearly nine out of ten targets by 2030, the United Nations has warned.

item.title: Grain ATMs and hunger maps: AI innovations spotlighted at UN agency showcase in India
item.description: Artificial intelligence solutions that transform the way food assistance reaches people facing hunger were on display during an exhibition at an AI meeting this week in New Delhi, India.

item.title: Floods, drought and insecurity drive acute hunger for 7.5 million in Pakistan
item.description: After a year that saw heavy monsoon floods, prolonged drought and dry spells, and a surge in violence, 7.5 million people in Pakistan face high levels of food insecurity and malnutrition according to a report from the global hunger monitor.

item.title: Special edition: As multilateralism fractures, Africa seeks a more perfect union
item.description: The African Continental Free Trade Area takes center stage at the AU Summit, and the U.S. seeks to pilot a new African cross-border infrastructure corridor, promising that investments would not be exploitative.

item.title: What’s behind US states joining WHO’s outbreak response system
item.description: Global health experts see the decision of the states of California, New York, and Illinois as both practical and symbolic.

item.title: Brazil Can Boost Growth by Bringing More Women into the Labor Force
item.description: When Brazil’s unemployment rate dropped to 5.2 percent in November 2025—the lowest in a quarter century—it punctuated an impressive turnaround from the pandemic. Yet, while men’s participation in the labor market has returned to its pre-COVID trend, women have fallen behind significantly. Getting more people into jobs is especially important because, in Brazil as in […]

item.title: From Grief to Guns: Baloch Women in Conflict
item.description: Fozia Shashani, 26, a member of the Baloch Yakjehti Committee, said it was “most painful” to hear reports that two Baloch women – Hawa Baloch, 20, and Asifa Mengal, 24 – had taken part in active combat as suicide bombers. The path, she said, was in complete contrast to her belief in peaceful resistance. Yet, […]

item.title: CEPI seeks $2.5B to address health threats, including AI-enabled risks
item.description: “If we’re fully funded through our new strategy, we think we can cover over three-quarters of the threats that may emerge today and in the coming years,” Aurélia Nguyen, CEPI’s deputy chief executive officer, tells Devex.

item.title: Scoop: US looks to pilot next African trade corridor project
item.description: Officials are seeking input on which cross-border project to back under the new U.S.–AU infrastructure working group.

item.title: USAID El Salvador closed with $1.9M in assets donated, disposed
item.description: One of the donated assets includes a Ford Explorer, which was transferred to El Salvador's Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

item.title: USAID El Salvador closed with $1.1M in assets donated, disposed
item.description: One of the donated assets includes a Ford Explorer, which was transferred to El Salvador's Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

item.title: International Humanitarian Law is at Breaking Point – but not Beyond Repair
item.description: International humanitarian law is at a breaking point, as rampant impunity for serious violations is enabling even greater abuses against civilians and detainees. Across today’s wars, violations are no longer concealed or exceptional. They are increasingly open, systematic, and unpunished, with catastrophic consequences for those whom the law is supposed to protect. New analysis of […]

item.title: Devex Invested: A need for speed — inside US DFC’s new vision
item.description: We bring you an in-depth interview with the U.S. International Development Finance Corporation investment chief Conor Coleman. Plus, what went down at the Munich Security Conference, and why are there so many “zombie funds”?

item.title: The Global Struggle for Equality for Women and Girls
item.description: The global struggle for equality for women and girls has been ongoing for centuries, with no single country having achieved full equality. In many countries, women and girls continue to face discrimination, harassment, unequal treatment, injustice, domestic violence, and a lack of security and safety. One of the primary goals of this struggle is to […]

item.title: Ex-NATO chief warns against boosting defense budgets at expense of aid
item.description: Former NATO chief George Robertson calls on the next U.N. secretary-general to refuse the post unless the P5 veto is suspended and warns against reducing aid budgets to fund national defense.

item.title: The best thing a nonprofit leader can do? Build beyond themselves
item.description: Opinion: Growth is the metric funders celebrate — but it may be quietly breaking your organization. Here's how charismatic leaders can build systems that outlast them.

item.title: What it’s like to be a grant writer right now
item.description: With fewer resources available, Devex asks those whose job it is to secure funding how the work currently feels.

item.title: The problem with ‘zombie funds’
item.description: Nearly a year after its launch, the Cali Fund has raised just $1,000 — highlighting how underfunded global funds can linger for years without delivering results.

item.title: Devex Newswire: Kenya’s girls face a new reality without US-funded program
item.description: The dire humanitarian consequences of the termination of the DREAMS program; the ongoing battle over the dismissal of Oxfam GB chief; and the investment case for funding women’s, children’s, and adolescents’ health care in Africa.

item.title: Four years of war in Ukraine: Childhood has ‘moved underground’, displacement continues – UN humanitarians
item.description: Civilian suffering shows no sign of letting up in Ukraine as the four-year-mark of Russia’s full-scale invasion nears amid attacks on energy infrastructure, blackouts and freezing temperatures, UN humanitarians warned on Tuesday.

item.title: Epstein files: ‘No one is too wealthy or too powerful to be above the law’; rights experts demand accountability
item.description: The large-scale disclosure of materials known as the “Epstein Files” has revealed “disturbing and credible evidence” of what independent human rights experts describe as a possible global criminal enterprise involving systematic sexual abuse, trafficking and exploitation of women and girls.

item.title: Sudan crisis: UN agency launches $1.6 billion appeal to support refugees in seven countries
item.description: As the war in Sudan approaches a fourth year, the UN refugee agency, UNHCR, and 123 partners appealed on Tuesday for $1.6 billion to support millions of people forced to flee the country in pursuit of safety.

item.title: Maternal deaths spike during war and instability, new report warns
item.description: Nearly two thirds of all maternal deaths worldwide occur in countries marked by conflict or fragility, according to a report released on Tuesday by the World Health Organization (WHO) and partners.

item.title: World News in Brief: Madagascar cyclone response, Gaza medical evacuations, remembering civil rights icon Jesse Jackson
item.description: At least 52 people have died after Tropical Cyclone Gezani made landfall on the eastern coast of Madagascar on 10 February, the UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) said on Tuesday, citing the authorities.

item.title: Ramadan in Gaza: Deprivation, high prices and the hardships of displacement
item.description: Palestinian Walid Al-Assi was playing with his young granddaughter this week, promising to take her to the market in Gaza City with the arrival of the holy month of Ramadan as his family had done before the Israel-Hamas war, but now circumstances had changed.

item.title: Migrants and refugees in Libya subjected to ‘systematic’ abuse: UN report
item.description: Migrants, refugees and asylum-seekers in Libya are enduring ruthless and systematic human rights violations, including killings, torture, sexual violence and trafficking, according to a new report published today by the UN human rights office, OHCHR.

item.title: Humanitarian access to Gaza still insufficient for relief and rebuilding: UN development chief
item.description: The UN has the funds and capacity to scale up relief and reconstruction operations in Gaza but does not have the necessary access to carry out these vital tasks, Alexander De Croo, the head of the UN Development Programme (UNDP), told journalists on Tuesday.

item.title: The Veto May be the Weapon of Elimination in the Election of Next UN Chief
item.description: As the campaign for the next Secretary-General gathers momentum– at a relatively slow pace– there is widespread speculation that any candidate running for the post of UN chief will have to abide by the dictates of a politically-hostile White House or face a veto in the Security Council. So far, there are only two declared […]

item.title: From Pledges to Proof: UN Biodiversity Meeting Begins First Global Review of Nature Action
item.description: Governments convened in Rome on Monday (February 16) for a critical round of UN biodiversity negotiations, launching the world’s first global review of how countries are acting to protect nature. The sixth meeting of the Subsidiary Body on Implementation (SBI-6) of the Convention on Biological Diversity opened at the headquarters of the Food and Agriculture […]

item.title: Totally Baffling: US Cuts Funding for the Prevention of Extremism
item.description: The Trump administration’s recent withdrawal of funding from international organizations is incomprehensible. A presidential memorandum of Jan. 7 lists dozens of international organizations that can no longer count on United States support, including the 30-nation Global Counterterrorism Forum, the European Centre of Excellence for Countering Hybrid Threats and the Global Community Engagement and Resilience Fund ... Read more

item.title: IRAN: ‘Sustainable Change Will Depend on Domestic Organisational Capacity, Not External Force’
item.description: CIVICUS discusses the recent protests in Iran with Sohrab Razaghi, executive director of Volunteer Activists, a Netherlands-based diaspora organisation empowering Iranian civil society. Protests triggered by economic grievances erupted across Iran on 28 December, quickly evolving into broader anti-regime protests. The crackdown that followed resulted in what may be the largest massacre in modern […]

item.title: Steep aid cuts put slow gains against female genital mutilation at risk
item.description: In places where female genital mutilation is deeply embedded in local traditions, progress toward ending it is slow. Now, sharp cuts to foreign aid have hindered global efforts to eliminate FGM, including funding reductions from the U.S. and U.K.

item.title: Ousted Oxfam CEO lambastes charity for 'brutal' dismissal
item.description: Halima Begum has now offered more details on her own account of the ongoing governance crisis at Oxfam GB.

item.title: Money Matters: Which multilateral agencies got the most funding?
item.description: We analyzed donor funding for multilaterals before the aid cuts of the past year. Plus, an in-depth interview with the U.S. DFC investment chief, and the impact of lost funding in Zimbabwe.

item.title: What did donors spend on multilateral aid in 2024?
item.description: With roughly $91 billion in official development assistance, the multilateral system plays a crucial role in advancing the Sustainable Development Goals.

item.title: After US aid cuts, South Africa’s HIV response strains to hold the line
item.description: The withdrawal of U.S. support has shuttered community clinics, strained public hospitals, and forced South Africa to rethink how it funds HIV care. But one year after USAID's collapse, South Africa is beginning to pick up the pieces.

item.title: Special edition: Development plays defense at Munich Security Conference
item.description: As world leaders at the Munich Security Conference declared the old order dead, global development found itself wondering about its place in the conversation over what's next.

item.title: A Q&A with DFC investment chief Conor Coleman
item.description: Conor Coleman opens up about DFC’s post-reauthorization road map, including fewer bigger deals, plans for New York-based dealmaking, high-income country investments, and a proactive pursuit of "tangible wins."

item.title: Cholera prevention campaigns resume after years of vaccine scarcity
item.description: Multiple efforts helped boost the supply of oral cholera vaccines, and more manufacturers could join the market in the future. But declines in global health funding could have an impact on the future of cholera prevention.

item.title: Devex Pro Insider: A tough week for Gates, a better week for French Gates
item.description: As Bill Gates becomes more engulfed in the Jeffrey Epstein scandal, Melinda French Gates is featured on Forbes' World’s Most Powerful Women list. Plus, previews of the African Union Summit and Munich Security Conference.

item.title: Devex Newswire: US Development Finance Corporation pursues dual mandate
item.description: DFC is gaining influence under the Trump administration, prompting a question: Will it prioritize more lucrative "America First" investments at the expense of its core development mission? Plus, is defense fighting development at the Munich Security Conference?

item.title: Aid leaders resist a zero-sum world as defense budgets climb
item.description: Speaking at the Munich Security Conference, Aurora Humanitarian Initiative CEO Armine Afeyan argues humanitarian action must not be subsumed into security agendas as governments prioritize rearmament.

item.title: Pentagon veteran says development is 'essential' for American security
item.description: Celeste Wallander says aid remains central to U.S. security strategy and Democrats must make that case again as defense spending rises and USAID’s future hangs in the balance.

item.title: UN chief urges renewed push to complete decolonization as 17 territories remain
item.description: More than 60 years after the UN launched its formal decolonization drive, Secretary-General António Guterres on Monday urged renewed commitment to completing the unfinished business of ending colonial rule.

item.title: Sudan: Thousands cling to a fragile hope in makeshift tents
item.description: The Tawila camp for internally displaced in Sudan’s war-torn Darfur region is home to more than half a million people who live in makeshift huts of sticks, hay and plastic sheeting.

item.title: As conditions worsen in Ukraine, refugees struggle to return
item.description: As Ukraine prepares to enter the fifth year of the full-scale Russian invasion on 24 February, UN monitors say harm to civilians has “demonstrably worsened”, while energy attacks and freezing temperatures are making it harder for displaced families to return.

item.title: UN forum calls for overhaul of agrifood systems
item.description: Rising food prices and declining farm incomes are putting increasing pressure on the global food system, with up to 720 million people facing hunger last year, and billions more struggling to afford healthy diets.

item.title: World News in Brief: Madagascar hunger crisis, Colombia aid appeal, Cuba fuel shortages
item.description: Back-to-back cyclones in Madagascar have left more than 400,000 people in need of food assistance, according to estimates by the UN World Food Programme (WFP), while roads, power lines and homes have been severely damaged.

item.title: Guterres deplores Israel’s move to resume land registration in the West Bank
item.description: UN Secretary-General António Guterres has condemned Israel’s decision to resume land registration procedures in a large part of the occupied West Bank, his Spokesman said on Monday.

item.title: Devex Pro Insider: USAID's terminators, Hungary Helps, and a post-DOGE Peace Corps
item.description: Some USAID employees tasked with shutting down the agency to be kept on until September. Plus, the Peace Corps survived DOGE, but what's next for the agency?

item.title: Senior DFC official details agency's plans, new vision
item.description: Armed with an expanded mandate and a focus on "tangible wins," DFC leadership moves to align the agency with private-sector speed and President Trump's geopolitical goals.

item.title: We Must Reject a World Governed by Raw Power
item.description: 2026 has begun on a deeply troubling note. International law, long regarded as the backbone of global peace and security, is being challenged in ever more brazen ways. Core principles of sovereignty and restraint are being flagrantly breached. I have recently returned from the World Economic Forum in Davos, where President Trump unveiled his new […]

item.title: Regional Trade in Transition: Digitalization, Servicing and De-risking
item.description: Trade in the Asia-Pacific region has moved into a new strategic reality. The latest Asia-Pacific Trade and Investment Trends (APTIT) highlights that rapid technological change and a strategic reconfiguration of supply chains are reshaping how economies in the region trade and compete. Rather than pursuing cost efficiency alone, firms and governments are increasingly prioritizing supply […]

item.title: Extreme Heat Undermines Decent Work in North Eastern Kenya
item.description: By 9 a.m. on a Wednesday, Hawa Hussein Farah is already watching the temperature climb. Awake since 6 a.m., she has prepared her three children for school before walking them to class and heading to Suuq Mugdi, an open-air market in Garissa town, to buy the fruit she will sell. When she settles into her […]

item.title: This week in global development
item.description: This Week in Global Development is Devex’s podcast series covering the top stories from the global development sector.

item.title: Can the Basel Treaty Fix Informal E-Waste Economies?
item.description: LAGOS, Nigeria — Near the Alaba International Market in Lagos, one of Africa’s largest electronics trading hubs, a sprawling dump of discarded phones, batteries and cables smolders at the edge of residential neighborhoods. Thick smoke rises daily from burning wires and broken appliances, carrying a toxic mix of lead, cadmium and other hazardous chemicals into ... Read more

item.title: World Entrepreneurs and Investment Forum puts women at the heart of economic transformation
item.description: Women entrepreneurs must be recognized as the architects of economic change and not the beneficiaries.

item.title: In the hands of innovators from the Global South, AI can transform lives
item.description: Artificial intelligence is no longer the sole preserve of rich western nations. The applications for the Global South, in areas ranging from health to agriculture and industry, are having a transformative effect on people’s lives.

item.title: Guterres tells AU Summit: ‘This is 2026 – not 1946’ in push for reform
item.description: Calling for sweeping reforms of global institutions, UN Secretary-General António Guterres told African leaders on Saturday that the absence of permanent African seats on the Security Council is “indefensible,” declaring: “This is 2026 – not 1946.”

item.title: New recombinant mpox strain detected in UK and India, WHO urges continued monitoring
item.description: The detection of a newly identified recombinant mpox virus containing genetic material from two known strains underscores the need for continued genomic surveillance, the UN World Health Organization (WHO) said on Saturday, as the overall global public health risk assessment remains unchanged.

item.title: [UN: Feb. 13] New Flareups Over Francesca Albanese, Norwegian Diplomacy Takes a Hit & Lots More
item.description: This Week @UN: UK’s women’s rights agenda; battling for a woman SecGen; Board of Peace’s only Palestinian woman. Plus: West Bank encroachments; South Sudan’s volatility; Ukraine’s front line; France lashes out; Haiti’s gang recruitments; #1 olive oil producer. • Stay current in real time on Blue Sky, Twitter (X), Facebook, Instagram, and LinkedIn. • Our #1 ... Read more

item.title: Trump hasn't killed the Peace Corps. Can he save it?
item.description: Having weathered the storm of DOGE, the 65-year-old bastion of American soft power faces what could be an even more daunting challenge: adapting to the modern world.

item.title: Multilateralism Reaching Breaking Point
item.description: The latest World Economic Forum made clear the current crisis of multilateralism. Over 60 heads of state and 800 corporate executives assembled in Davos under a ‘Spirit of Dialogue’ theme aimed at strengthening global cooperation, but it was preceded by a series of events pointing to a further unravelling of the international system. On 3 […]

item.title: Africa at the Epicenter of Child Labour Crisis as Migration Fuels Exploitation
item.description: Although global rates of child labour have declined since 2020, the practice remains a serious and persistent violation of children’s rights, undermining their safety, social development, and long-term economic stability. These risks are intensified by structural pressures— poverty, climate shocks, protracted conflict, and unsafe migration— that continue to push vulnerable children into crisis, and in […]

item.title: Devex Career Hub: How and where to develop AI skills
item.description: This week: What development career experts advise on how to gain and utilize AI skills; how some have pivoted post-USAID; featured new job leads; and much more.

item.title: Africa’s future depends on investing in women, children, adolescents
item.description: Opinion: At this week’s AU Summit, Africa faces a choice: Continue with preventable maternal and child deaths and structural barriers to women’s and girls’ well-being, or make the investments needed to build resilient health systems.

item.title: Life after DREAMS: Kenya’s girls navigate HIV risk without US support
item.description: The end of the PEPFAR-funded DREAMS program cut off HIV-prevention support for millions of girls across sub-Saharan Africa. In Kenya, health experts warn the consequences are already visible.

item.title: The top global development organizations hiring in Switzerland
item.description: Devex examines which organizations are doing the most hiring in Switzerland, from U.N. agencies to humanitarian groups.

item.title: The UN can’t reform itself with yesterday’s leaders
item.description: Opinion: “Without generational renewal at the top, the U.N. reform risks becoming little more than an exercise in delay management.”

item.title: Devex Newswire: Defense spending surges as development budgets slide

item.description: In a talk with Shelly Helgeson of Connective Impact, we examine how closed funding pipelines, lower risk tolerance, and the loss of USAID are reshaping philanthropy — and why relationship building now matters more than ever.

item.title: Where is HIV prevention drug lenacapavir in ‘America First’ health deals?
item.description: Opinion: Omitting HIV prevention targets from these deals will be devastating to the affordability and scale-up of the drug lenacapavir. African leaders can change that.

item.title: The new power players
item.description: We discuss the new Devex Power 50 list and explore how shifting geopolitical dynamics, the rise of AI, and a growing push for resource sovereignty in Africa are redefining the traditional landscape of global development.

item.title: The post-Axel era at the World Bank
item.description: Axel van Trotsenburg has retired from the bank's second-highest role after nearly four decades. What does his departure mean for the multilateral lender, and what kind of legacy does he leave behind?

item.title: UK aid agency should pause reforms, says parliamentary committee
item.description: Fearing a brain drain, parliamentarians called to pause in-progress reforms to U.K. aid.

item.title: Why ending US food aid to Afghanistan, Yemen threatens national security
item.description: Opinion: The U.S. administration’s justifications to cut all food aid to these two countries are questionable, and create conditions for political instability inconsistent with U.S. interests.

item.title: The skills you need to work in globaldev communications
item.description: Understanding how to reach different audiences and strong judgement in the use of AI are among the skills required.

item.title: Anna Bjerde: Country compacts are a 'game-changer' for World Bank
item.description: Anna Bjerde explains why country-owned compacts, stronger cross-border connectivity along the Lobito Corridor, and water are emerging as core pillars of the bank’s Africa agenda.

item.title: Devex CheckUp: WHO’s next leader might need to be a unicorn
item.description: What kind of leader does the World Health Organization need next? And does that person even exist? Plus, the Gates Foundation doubles down on goals, and a new study reveals that over 200 million people could die due to aid cuts.

item.title: Devex Newswire: Africa’s bid to take charge of its critical minerals
item.description: Inside Africa’s high stakes push for mineral sovereignty; Liberia’s foreign affairs minister tells us why her country is pivoting to economic diplomacy; and how to run a smarter job search in 2026.

item.title: UN lauds $6 billion US funding approval towards ending HIV/AIDS
item.description: The UN agency leading the global effort to end HIV/AIDS worldwide welcomed legislative approval from the United States on Thursday for a $6 billion spending package to help tackle the disease, following nearly a year of sharp aid cuts.

item.title: Cuba: UN warns of possible humanitarian ‘collapse’, as oil supplies dwindle
item.description: The UN on Wednesday warned of potential humanitarian “collapse” in Cuba, following Washington’s attempt to block oil supplies from reaching the island.

item.title: ‘Human rights cannot wait’: Türk launches $400 million appeal for 2026
item.description: UN High Commissioner for Human Rights Volker Türk launched a $400 million appeal on Thursday in Geneva, as his office (OHCHR) continues to operate “in survival mode”.

item.title: Child malnutrition hits catastrophic levels in parts of Sudan
item.description: Acute malnutrition among children has reached catastrophic levels in parts of Sudan’s North Darfur and Greater Kordofan, UN-backed analysts warned on Thursday, as conflict, mass displacement and denials of aid push the country deeper into a famine-risk emergency.

item.title: M23 rebels: UN sees progress in talks but warns violence persists
item.description: The United Nations has welcomed signs of progress in talks aimed at reducing violence in eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo.

item.title: UN Police ‘indispensable’ to fulfilling peacekeeping mandates, Security Council hears
item.description: The head of UN Peacekeeping on Thursday called for greater support for international police officers deployed to field missions at a time when financial resources are dwindling and multilateralism is waning.

item.title: Chad: Africa’s refugee haven struggles with its own stark challenges
item.description: Amid the ongoing war in Sudan, Chad, the country receiving the most refugees in Central Africa, saw slight improvements in its humanitarian situation last year, but as one of the most vulnerable nations on the African continent, it is still struggling to support four million people in need.

item.title: World News in Brief: UN condemns attack on civilians in Nigeria, updates from Gaza and West Bank, relief flights to resume in Yemen
item.description: The UN Secretary-General on Thursday strongly condemned a deadly terrorist attack in Kwara state in western Nigeria, where more than 100 people were reportedly killed.

item.title: Fatwas, faith and fallacies: Myth-busting female genital mutilation in Africa
item.description: Olivia Albert, 19, was subjected to female genital (FGM) mutilation when she was 14. She told the UN sexual and reproductive health agency (UNFPA) that she hid her pain because everyone around her said it was normal.

item.title: What kind of leader does WHO need next?
item.description: The World Health Organization director-general elections are taking place in 2027, but expect candidates to come forward this year in the lead-up to the World Health Assembly. Whoever takes up the mantle at the agency will have their work cut out for them.

item.title: Africa’s health security is global security
item.description: Opinion: Africa’s health security is global security. As aid contracts and risks grow, Africa is building sovereign, continent-led systems — proving that resilience, not dependence, is the strategy for a safer world.

item.description: Melanie Brown has been fishing salmon in Bristol Bay, Alaska, for more than 30 years. An Indigenous fisherwoman and a coordinating committee member of the World Forum of Fisher Peoples, she speaks about the sea with deep care and lived knowledge. When interviewed for IPS on Marine Protected Areas (MPAs), a global conservation policy introduced […]

item.title: To Fix the Rupture, Trade is not Enough
item.description: Will trade be enough to navigate the current waves of chaos and disorder that are underpinning the ongoing rifts among competing powerful and hegemon nations and the rest? Amid tectonic shifts in the realm of geopolitics and international relations, amid what the Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney recently defined as a “rupture” in the rules-based […]

item.title: The US foreign aid shock of 2025 gives way to a rapidly evolving 2026
item.description: Devex reporters reflect on the upheaval of last year and where that leaves the development community this year.

item.title: How Africa’s development job market is changing in 2026
item.description: Business models are shifting and there's demand for professionals with problem solving and donor skills. But it's a highly competitive job market and salaries are not what they used to be.

item.title: Devex Dish: The migrant workers who feed the world
item.description: Migrant labor underpins global food production — and in some places, policies are finally starting to catch up. Plus, Washington updates and highlights from Devex’s Power 50 in food and agriculture.

item.description: The approved $50 billion compromise foreign affairs spending bill surpasses the White House's proposals but includes a significant reduction in humanitarian funding compared to previous levels. Plus, a democracy NGO faces down its would-be defunders.

item.title: Welcome to the ‘agrihood’ – the neighbourhood of the future?
item.description: Towns and cities are home to more than half of the world’s population and responsible for around 70 per cent of the greenhouse gas emissions driving the climate crisis, which is why urban planners in Brazil are leading a design revolution that could point the way to creating built-up areas with a dramatically smaller carbon footprint.

item.title: ‘Deepfake abuse is abuse,’ UNICEF warns
item.description: New evidence reveals a proliferation of sexualised images of youngsters generated by artificial intelligence (AI) and a dearth of laws to stop it, the UN Children’s Fund (UNICEF) warned on Wednesday.

item.description: The UN on Wednesday announced the list of experts nominated to the General Assembly to serve on a new Independent International Scientific Panel tasked with assessing how AI is transforming lives worldwide.

item.title: South Sudan: UN forced to suspend food aid after ‘unacceptable’ attacks on convoy
item.description: South Sudan is buckling under a fresh wave of violence and displacement, after attacks and looting halted a major UN food convoy in restive Upper Nile state and clashes continue to spread in neighbouring Jonglei.

item.title: ‘We are dying’: Gaza’s cancer patients plead for a way out
item.description: As World Cancer Day is marked on Wednesday, thousands of patients in Gaza face worsening illness, untreated pain and closed crossings – despite the limited opening of the vital route through Rafah this week.

item.description: The terrorist group ISIL continues to adapt and demonstrate resilience despite sustained counter-terrorism efforts, a senior UN official told the Security Council on Wednesday.

item.description: UN Secretary-General António Guterres has warned that the expiration of the New START treaty represents a “grave moment” for international peace and security, as binding limits on US and Russian strategic nuclear weapons fall away amid heightened global tensions.

item.description: Opinion: Changing global realities requires fresh thinking on development finance for gender equality. Updated strategies and coalitions can support new investments.

item.description: Opinion: The upcoming World Health Assembly can accelerate the responsible use of artificial intelligence in health by grounding action in the ethical and responsible access and use of health data.

item.title: UN Secretary-General to outline 2026 priorities at noon press conference
item.description: UN Secretary-General António Guterres will hold his official start-of-the-year press conference today at noon in New York, setting out his priorities for 2026 and why the UN has a crucial and positive role to play in an increasingly unstable and dangerous world. Speaking to journalists at UN Headquarters, he is expected to outline the major challenges facing the international community and the best path ahead.

item.title: World News in Brief: IOM warning for Sudan returnees, Nipah virus alert for India, food security in Afghanistan
item.description: In Sudan, where the devastating conflict between the Sudanese army and rival paramilitary Rapid Support Forces is nearing the end of its third year, more than three million people have returned to their areas of origin, the International Organization for Migration (IOM) announced on Thursday.

item.title: UN chief ‘deeply concerned’ by escalation of violence in South Sudan
item.description: The world's youngest country, South Sudan, is facing continued instability and violence as military escalation looms, following reports earlier this week that a senior army commander had called on troops to inflict indiscriminate violence against civilians in Jonglei state.

item.title: Violence roiling Nigeria extends beyond religious lines, amid a deepening humanitarian crisis
item.description: When the United States ordered airstrikes on Christmas Day against Islamist militants in northern Nigeria, officials in Washington said the action was aimed at protecting Christians facing threats of violence.

item.title: AI for all: The path to inclusive growth
item.description: AI was central to the WEF agenda, but its value exceeds return on investment. How can we reframe AI as an opportunity to better serve society? Experts convened in Davos to discuss building an inclusive digital future for all.

item.title: ‘We continue to follow his light:’ World mourns health giant William Foege
item.description: A pioneer behind smallpox eradication and leader of numerous global health bodies, Dr. William H. Foege's passing has triggered an outpouring of admiration.

item.title: How aid cuts are shaking up development academia
item.description: Last year's reductions in official development assistance and widespread layoffs across the sector are shifting demand for development courses and teaching positions.

item.title: Heba Aly on the fight to give two-thirds of the world a seat at the UN
item.description: Article 109 Director Heba Aly calls for the U.N. to deliver on its core purpose of maintaining peace and security, and highlights the need for a new global social contract and a more inclusive and effective multilateral system.

item.title: Trump’s ‘Donroe Doctrine’ redraws US foreign aid map
item.description: The strategy channels 40% of U.S. aid to the Western Hemisphere and East Asia, and ties foreign assistance to security, trade, and loyalty.

item.title: ‘Unfathomable But Avoidable’ Suffering in Gaza Hospitals, Says Volunteer Nurse
item.description: Damages from the war and significant restrictions on medical supplies mean that "people in Gaza are still suffering from completely avoidable misery and harm." - Sam Zarifi, Executive Director of Physicians for Human Rights (PHR)

item.title: Melting Reserves of Power: Mongolia’s Glaciers and the Future of Energy and Food Security
item.description: The International Year of Glaciers’ Preservation in 2025 was a timely reminder that the stability of Mongolia’s economy rests on fragile mountain systems that are melting faster than ever recorded. The loss reverberates across the country’s energy and agricultural systems, two development pillars that draw from the same finite resource: water. Warming and glacial retreat […]

item.title: USDA takes over Food for Peace with $452M World Food Programme deal
item.description: The agreement with WFP steers U.S.-grown commodities through an America First foreign aid approach — one that will lead to bulk purchases by March.

item.title: Innovations fast-tracking the end of sleeping sickness in the DRC
item.description: In this episode of Escape the Neglect, Devex traces the extraordinary journey of transforming gambiense sleeping sickness treatment in the Democratic Republic of Congo — from painful, high-risk injections to a groundbreaking single-dose oral cure.

item.title: Gambia’s Supreme Court to Decide on FGM Ban
item.description: Gambia’s Supreme Court is considering whether a law protecting women and girls from female genital mutilation (FGM) is constitutional. The practice, common in Gambia, often involves forcibly restraining girls while parts of their genitals are cut, sometimes with the wound sewn shut. FGM constitutes torture and cruel, inhuman, or degrading treatment under international human rights […]

item.title: Adaptation offers a great bang for the buck — so why aren’t we buying?
item.description: Opinion: Despite an extraordinary economic payoff — every $1 spent on climate adaptation avoids up to $7 in damages — the world is spending less than half of what is needed, leaving billions of people unprotected.

item.title: The great reset: One year since the US aid freeze
item.description: One year ago, Devex broke the historic U.S. aid freeze. We revisit the 2025 stop-work order and the dismantling of USAID, marking a turning point for global development.

item.title: Devex Dish: A chilling problem for Africa’s food supply
item.description: In this edition: How a global cold-chain revolution can boost food security; why progress on food security remains so slow; and tackling the “global water bankruptcy” problem.

item.title: Talent Wasted: Afghanistan’s Educated Women Adapt Under Taliban Restrictions
item.description: The author is an Afghanistan-based female journalist, trained with Finnish support before the Taliban take-over. Her identity is withheld for security reasons

item.title: How a global cold-chain revolution can boost food security
item.description: In a warming world with a growing population, the market for sustainable cooling in developing economies is set to double to $600 billion by 2050. Investors and governments are just starting to pay attention.

item.title: Devex Newswire: Trump dramatically expands restrictions on aid groups
item.description: The Trump administration widens Mexico City Policy restrictions to include gender and DEI. Plus, the leader of one of the top U.S. nonprofits is moving on.

item.title: Security Council LIVE: Ambassadors debate as Middle East crises mount
item.description: The UN Security Council is holding a high-level open debate on the Middle East which is expected to focus on the Gaza peace plan – including the role of President Donald Trump’s Board of Peace – the continuing humanitarian crisis in the enclave and turmoil in the West Bank and East Jerusalem, following the demolition of UNRWA’s headquarters there. Follow live coverage below, and UN News app users can click here.

item.title: Potential turning point for Gaza as peace plan enters second phase: UN envoy
item.description: The start of a second phase of a stabilisation plan for Gaza offers a potential turning point for the war-ravaged enclave, a senior UN official told the Security Council on Wednesday.

item.title: ‘We children saw things that no one should ever have to see’ Holocaust survivor tells the UN
item.description: Holocaust survivor Marion Blumenthal Lazan, gave a harrowing and heart-rendering account of her childhood under Nazi persecution during Tuesday’s Holocaust Memorial event in New York, urging citizens worldwide to push back against ‘negativity’ by choosing “love, respect and compassion” in how they treat one another.

item.title: World News in Brief: UN Support Office in Haiti, Goodwill Ambassador Theo James in Syria, urgent appeal for millions in DR Congo
item.description: The Security Council-endorsed UN Support Office in Haiti is on track to deliver on behalf of the Haitian people, UN Spokesperson Stéphane Dujarric said on Wednesday.

item.title: Global aid is leaving the poorest behind, new report warns
item.description: Eurodad argues that technical reforms have diverted official development assistance away from poverty reduction and toward the commercial and political priorities of donor countries.

item.title: New US funding rules tie aid to abortion, gender ideology, DEI bans
item.description: The Trump administration’s Promoting Human Flourishing in Foreign Assistance Policy goes far past previous iterations of the Mexico City Policy to new funding, new constraints, and new organizations.

item.title: Exiled: Myanmar’s Resistance to Junta Rule Flourishes Abroad
item.description: From construction and hotel workers to kitchen and restaurant staff—estimates of the numbers of Myanmar migrants living in Thailand range up to six million, with a surge of new arrivals since the 2021 military coup. Many are building new lives in the vast metropolis of Bangkok, ranked by the UN among the world’s top 15 […]

item.title: ‘Since the Coup, Factory Employers Have Increasingly Worked with the Military to Restrict Organising and Silence Workers’
item.description: CIVICUS speaks to the Business and Human Rights Centre (BHRC) about labour rights abuses in Myanmar’s garment industry since the 2021 military coup. Myanmar’s garment sector, which employs hundreds of thousands of workers, is in deep crisis. Since the coup, labour protections have collapsed, independent unions have been dismantled and workers who try to […]

item.title: Haiti at a Crossroads: Political Uncertainty and Gang Control Push Nation Toward Collapse
item.description: As Haiti’s Transitional President Council (TPC) approaches its February 7 expiration date and the country remains without a newly elected president, humanitarian experts warn the nation risks further sliding into insecurity, raising fears of broader collapse. The United Nations (UN) notes that escalating violence by entrenched armed coalitions, persisting impunity for human rights abuses, political […]

item.title: Global South Demonstrates How Countries Can Deal with an Aggressive United States
item.description: The United States’ attack on Venezuela marks a key watershed in the world order. We still cannot predict how this violation of another state’s sovereignty will ultimately play out. But it has called into question the global order that is founded on sovereign equality. Experts talk of ‘imperialist imitation dynamics’ and a return to spheres […]

item.title: Exclusive: Tessie San Martin to step down from FHI 360's helm
item.description: San Martin will be stepping down from her role this calendar year, though she will continue to serve as the organization’s chief executive officer until a successor has been identified.

item.title: Who’s Afraid of the F-Word? The Next UN Leader Must Be a Woman and a Feminist
item.description: The United Nations General Assembly has officially opened the selection process for its next secretary-general, noting “with regret” that no woman has ever held the role and urging member states to “strongly consider” nominating women. After 80 years of male leadership and mounting global crises, the institution faces a choice: to repeat the past or ... Read more

item.title: Devex Invested: Will 2026 be the year development finance gets real?
item.description: Allianz launches a new blended finance fund, and the World Bank opens a new office in Qatar. Plus, all the trends we’re watching this year.

item.title: To power AI energy needs, nuclear is going to have a comeback
item.description: Opinion: Development finance can't ignore nuclear energy given the spread of AI, and should be creating conditions stable enough for long-term deployment in emerging markets.

item.title: Cuts Stall Clinical Trials, Scientists Warn US Risks Losing Its Research Edge
item.description: Scientists across the U.S., including me, are stressed after a year marked by several changes and challenges, including cuts to science funding that have stalled clinical trials and studies that could improve and save lives. Without funding, scientists worry about how they will support ongoing research and train America’s future workforce, including the next generation of innovators. […]

item.title: Binalakshmi Nepram: Engineering Peace, Creating History
item.description: It was Christmas eve: some two decades ago. Binalakshmi Nepram was a witness to the killing of a 27-year-old. In utter disbelief, she saw a group of three men dragging the victim from his workshop. Within minutes, he was shot dead. “Every day three or four people are shot dead in Manipur’s ongoing conflict. Thousands […]

item.title: A Not So Happy United States
item.description: The United States is not so happy. Its population has received a lower happiness ranking compared to previous years. The factors contributing to this decline have significant implications for the United States, both domestically and internationally. As Dostoevsky noted, “The greatest happiness is to know the source of unhappiness”. According to Gallup’s 2025 World Happiness […]

item.title: Devex Newswire: UN races on AI as budgets shrink and risks mount
item.description: Leaders at U.N. agencies stress that enthusiasm for AI tools usage has to be matched with guardrails, noting that although experimentation with AI is widespread within the U.N. system, results are mixed. Plus, where are the U.K.’s aid allocations?

item.title: Independent experts alarmed by child rights violations in US immigration procedures
item.description: UN-appointed independent human rights experts have raised alarm over violations of children’s rights during US immigration procedures, nearly a year after federal funding for legal representation for unaccompanied minors was terminated.

item.title: Remembering the Holocaust: ‘You are here because you choose hope over hate’
item.description: The Holocaust is a warning, that hatred “can consume everything” – a message that feels more urgent than ever, the UN chief said on Tuesday, as antisemitism rages worldwide.

item.title: Yemen: Security Council votes on final extension of Hudaydah Mission
item.description: The Security Council adopted a resolution on Tuesday that renews the mandate of the UN Mission in the Yemeni port city of Hudaydah for a final two-month period through 31 March of this year.

item.title: From lunch tray to lifelong health: WHO sets global standards for school meals
item.description: For the first time ever, the World Health Organization (WHO) is providing recommendations for healthy and nutritious food in schools around the world.

item.title: UN says Gaza crisis remains dire, children hardest hit
item.description: Despite a modest increase in humanitarian assistance, the situation in Gaza remains “dire”, with children among the hardest hit by shortages of shelter, basic services and education, the United Nations said on Tuesday.

item.title: BCG on scaling global impact in an era of constraints
item.description: BCG’s Jim Larson joins Devex’s Raj Kumar for a special edition podcast to discuss the "impact pivot," exploring how development leaders are leveraging generative AI, blended finance, and market-driven efficiencies to scale results despite global economic constraints.

item.title: As Korea Ages, Fiscal Reforms Can Help Safeguard Government Finances
item.description: Korea’s population is aging faster than almost any other country. That’s because people live longer than in most other countries, while the birth rate is one of the lowest in the world. About one-fifth of the population is 65 and older, more than triple the share in the 1990s. This matters because older people tend […]

item.title: From India to the world: Advancing quality maternal care at scale
item.description: Countries around the world are striving to reduce maternal mortality rates. In India, Manyata is showing what is possible through quality improvement and certification that is helping close the gap and strengthen national health systems.

item.description: U.K. aid minister Jenny Chapman also called the future of the country's independent aid watchdog into question

item.title: Money Matters: The US budget — a bigger cut than it seems?

item.title: The $50B US aid budget: What’s in it for development?
item.description: A breakdown of the compromise appropriations bill that defied the Trump administration’s ambition to cut foreign aid by nearly half.

item.title: Can the private sector help safeguard democracy? The answer is yes
item.description: Opinion: In order for civil society groups to successfully leverage the private sector’s potential in uplifting democratic principles, they must learn to speak the sector’s language.

item.title: Development finance trends to watch in 2026
item.description: From private capital mobilization, pressure on MDBs and DFIs, a geographic shift in focus and local currency solutions to greater self-interest. Here's what to expect.

item.title: Devex Newswire: The many sides and faces of Trump's global health cuts
item.description: How the U.S. aid cuts affected the lives of Ugandans living with HIV. Plus, the U.S. plans to stiff the World Health Organization on past due payments.

item.title: From deepfakes to grooming: UN warns of escalating AI threats to children
item.description: The staggering amount of harmful AI-generated online content has prompted an urgent call from across the UN system for a raft of measures to protect children from abuse, exploitation and mental trauma.

item.description: The head of embattled UN relief agency for Palestinians, UNRWA, has condemned reports that its headquarters in East Jerusalem have been set alight deliberately.

item.title: South Sudan: UN and rights experts warn against risk of mass violence in Jonglei
item.description: The UN Mission in South Sudan (UNMISS) is sounding the alarm over the threat of escalating violence in Jonglei state which is putting lives at risk and further weakening prospects for peace.

item.description: When fighting recently intensified near her neighbourhood in Aleppo, in northern Syria, Fatima and her family had to run.

item.title: UN chief warns ‘law of the jungle’ is replacing rule of law
item.description: Warning that the “rule of law is being replaced by the law of the jungle,” the UN Secretary-General on Monday urged world powers to recommit to international law as the foundation of peace, justice and multilateral cooperation.

item.title: ‘We must stand up for our shared humanity - each and every day’: UN human rights chief
item.description: On the eve of International Holocaust Remembrance Day, UN High Commissioner for Human Rights Volker Türk called on the global community to “not only to look at our past, but to reflect on our present, and to safeguard our future.”

item.title: Gaza ceasefire improves aid access, but children still face deadly conditions
item.description: The fragile ceasefire in the Gaza Strip is making a difference to the lives of over a million children, and improving overall access to food - but more aid still needs to enter.

item.description: The UN migration agency, IOM, expressed deep concern on Monday over multiple deadly shipwrecks that are believed to have taken place over the past ten days across the Central Mediterranean.

item.title: Uganda: Democracy in Name Only
item.description: When Ugandans went to the polls on 15 January, the outcome was never in doubt. As voting began, mobile internet services ground to a halt, ensuring minimal scrutiny as President Yoweri Museveni secured his seventh consecutive term. Far from offering democratic choice, the vote reinforced one of Africa’s longest-running presidencies, providing a veneer of democratic […]

item.title: What will it take for AI to work for women’s health in Africa?
item.description: Opinion: Maternal deaths remain catastrophically high across the continent despite decades of mobile health interventions. Artificial intelligence offers personalized, predictive care — if designed with the right safeguards.

item.title: One year after US aid freeze, HIV care in Africa is in retreat
item.description: One year after President Donald Trump froze U.S. foreign aid, HIV treatment still exists across much of Africa — but the outreach, prevention, and monitoring systems that sustained it are fraying. The Aid Report traces how those losses are reshaping access to care across Uganda, Zambia, Malawi, and Botswana.

item.title: Is the US Board of Peace Aimed at Undermining the UN?
item.description: Judging by the mixed signals coming out of the White House, is the Board of Peace, a creation of President Donald Trump, eventually aimed at replacing the UN Security Council or the United Nations itself? item.description: Highlights from Davos, and the latest career moves in the global development sector.

item.description: It has been one year since a global stop-work order brought U.S. foreign aid to a standstill — and set off a cascade of unforeseeable events that upended global development.

item.description: The international legal framework underpinning the United Nations has been under attack since the turn of the millennium. While United States President Trump is destroying what’s left of it, he has had many accomplices in its gradual yet tangible decline in the last 25 years. item.title: From family farm to climate tech: How one Kenyan woman is helping farmers outsmart drought
item.description: “Giving up is not an option - so many people depend on you,” the words of Maryanne Gichanga, a participant in a UN supported initiative, which aims to help farmers in Kenya find solutions to alleviate the pressures of climate change on agriculture production.

item.description: The senior UN official in Ukraine, Matthias Schmale, has issued a condemnation of the massive overnight Russian drone and missile strike on several major Ukrainian cities, killing and injuring civilians, and knocking out energy infrastructure amid sub-zero temperatures.

item.description: The World Health Organization (WHO) has issued a detailed statement regretting the United States decision to leave the UN agency, and declaring that it will leave both the US and the world less safe as a result.

item.description: Nearly four years into Russia’s full-scale invasion, Ukraine faces another winter marked by widespread humanitarian suffering and continued indiscriminate attacks. item.title: The Trump administration says it won't pay what it owes WHO
item.description: When the U.S. joined in 1948, Congress stipulated the country must pay what’s owed to the agency before it can withdraw — but the Trump administration says it's out and won't pay anything more.
