item.title: Can the US formally withdraw from WHO without paying its debts?
item.description: Paying what’s owed to the organization is one of the conditions of its withdrawal.

item.title: The latest from the World Economic Forum meeting in Davos
item.description: For the latest episode of our weekly podcast series, Senior Editor Rumbi Chakamba sits down with Devex President and Editor-in-Chief Raj Kumar and Global Development Reporter Elissa Miolene to bring you the latest from Davos.

item.title: Sen. Coons expects Senate to pass, Trump to sign $50B aid budget bill
item.description: At the World Economic Forum in Davos, the Democratic senator said he is hopeful that lawmakers will pass — and Trump will sign — a multimillion-dollar foreign aid funding bill currently being discussed on Capitol Hill.

item.title: Why Save the Children US prioritizes donor engagement skills in hiring
item.description: As the organization rebuilds its fundraising teams, its looking for experts with transferable skills to engage new donors.

item.title: Big Nature-Based Finance Turnaround Needed to Restore, Protect Ecosystems
item.description: The world is pouring trillions of dollars each year into activities that destroy nature while investing only a fraction of that amount in protecting and restoring the ecosystems on which economies depend, according to a new United Nations report released on today (January 22). The State of Finance for Nature 2026 report by the United Nations […]

item.title: World’s Oceans Hit Record Heat in 2025, at Great Economic and Social Costs
item.description: In 2025, global ocean temperatures rose to some of the highest levels ever recorded, signaling a continued accumulation of heat within the Earth’s climate system and raising deep concern among climate scientists. The economic toll of ocean-related impacts—including collapsing fisheries, widespread coral reef degradation, and mounting damage to coastal infrastructure—is now estimated to be nearly […]

item.title: Steering Nepal’s Economy Amid Global Challenges
item.description: Nepal has a unique opportunity for transformation. The recent youth-led protests underscored aspirations for greater transparency, governance and a more equal distribution of economic opportunities and resources. This yearning resonated in Nepal and beyond. Now, Nepal must find a balance in setting prudent political, economic and financial policies to steer a difficult transition in an […]

item.title: Billionaire wealth grows 3 times faster than ever before, Oxfam warns
item.description: As the richest pile up trillions, Oxfam warns their growing fortunes are translating into outsized political power.

item.title: Low-resource nations may leapfrog wealthier ones in using AI for health
item.description: That's what Bill Gates and Peter Sands said during a conversation at the World Economic Forum.

item.title: Latvia Sheds Its Quiet Ways as a New Member of the UN Security Council
Devex Dish: The big questions as USDA takes over Food for Peace
item.description: USAID’s flagship food aid program finds a home — albeit a temporary one, at the U.S. Department of Agriculture. Plus, AGRA’s “rainbow revolution” for Africa, and we remember legendary agricultural scientist Pedro Sánchez.

item.title: After USAID, Food for Peace enters a new and uncertain chapter
item.description: A temporary agreement moves Food for Peace to the U.S. Department of Agriculture, raising questions about whether the shift will alter the program’s core mission and whether the agency can manage its scale.

item.title: Davos Dispatch: A jittery Davos sits in the shadow of Trump
item.description: As leaders gather at the 2026 World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, under mounting inequality and fraying alliances, U.S. President Donald Trump dominates the room — and the stakes feel higher than ever.

item.title: Devex Newswire: From USAID layoffs to the campaign trail
item.description: Following the dismantling of USAID, thousands of development professionals were left jobless. In response, some former USAID insiders have decided to run for office. Plus, the U.N. moves more workers out of the U.S.

item.title: When business moves faster than politics
item.description: Opinion: In a world of rising trade conflicts and declining investment in development, sustainability is being framed as an economic burden. UNIDO has launched a global business award designed to challenge that narrative. But do companies care?

item.title: Haiti explained: why the crisis is deepening — and what comes next
item.description: Haiti is entering 2026 facing one of the most complex crises in its recent history. On Wednesday, the Caribbean island nation will be high on the international agenda as the UN Security Council holds its first meeting of the year to update ambassadors.

item.title: Cold kills another infant in Gaza as West Bank displacement intensifies
item.description: Another child in the Gaza Strip has died from hypothermia as winter weather continues to whip the enclave, the UN said on Wednesday, citing information from the health authorities.

item.title: UN Assembly president defends multilateralism, UN Charter in Davos
item.description: From Davos, the President of the UN General Assembly on Wednesday warned that the world has entered a “make‑or‑break” moment for multilateralism, saying the rules‑based order can survive only if states speak the truth and act when it’s hard. She called for a cross‑regional alliance to push back against growing lawlessness, disinformation, and power‑based politics.

item.title: Haiti crisis at breaking point as gangs tighten grip ahead of transition deadline
item.description: Haiti’s deepening crisis has reached a critical phase, senior UN officials warned the Security Council on Wednesday, as powerful gangs continue to expand their control across the country.

item.title: Amid water stress, experts want the world to get serious about irrigation
item.description: As climate change strains water resources, experts say flexible, locally led irrigation may hold the key to food security.

item.title: Thousands of Kenya’s Smallholder Coffee Farmers Risk Losing EU Market as Deforestation Law Takes Effect
item.description: For the last twenty years, Sarah Nyaga, a smallholder farmer from Embu County in central Kenya, has farmed coffee. Like most across Kenya, she relies on the export market. A greater percentage of Kenya’s coffee ends up within the European Union market, but a new law threatens to disrupt what has been a source of […]

item.title: Trump dismantled USAID. Now these aid workers are running for office
item.description: For a growing group of former USAID and development professionals, the sector’s collapse has sparked a new response: running for political office.

item.title: World Enters “Era of Global Water Bankruptcy”
item.description: The world is already in the state of “water bankruptcy”. In many basins and aquifers, long-term overuse and degradation mean that past hydrological and ecological baselines cannot realistically be restored. While not every basin or country is water-bankrupt, enough critical systems around the world have crossed these thresholds, and are interconnected through trade, migration, climate […]

item.title: Davos post-Schwab: Can new leadership restore trust, or just rebrand the club?
item.description: Opinion: The exit of the World Economic Forum's founder and a new era of Wall Street cochairs signal a Davos less rooted in grand visions, and development groups should prepare accordingly.

item.title: Bulldozing UNRWA’s HQ Is an Attack on the UN, Spokesperson Says
item.description: The United Nations on Tuesday condemned Israel’s demolition of the headquarters compound of the UN Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees (UNRWA), in East Jerusalem, describing the move as an attack on the world body itself. Farhan Haq, the deputy spokesperson for Secretary-General António Guterres, rejected the Israeli claim that the compound had stopped ... Read more

item.title: Guinea’s Path to Electoral Autocracy
item.description: In December, the dust settled on Guinea’s first presidential election since the military took control in a 2021 coup. General Mamady Doumbouya stayed in power after receiving 87 per cent of the vote. But the outcome was never in doubt: this was no a democratic milestone; it was the culmination of Guinea’s denied transition to […]

item.title: World Living Beyond Its Means: Warns UN’s Global Water Bankruptcy Report
item.description: The world has entered what United Nations researchers now describe as an era of Global Water Bankruptcy, a condition where humanity has irreversibly overspent the planet’s water resources, leaving ecosystems, economies, and communities unable to recover to previous levels. The new report, released by the United Nations University Institute for Water, Environment and Health, titled Global Water […]

item.title: Devex Invested: A year of new partners, new presidents, and new promises
item.description: As Western aid declines, the future of global development finance is shifting toward private capital, Gulf funds, and domestic revenue.

item.title: From breakthroughs to better lives: The path to dengue-free communities
item.description: In Brazil, scientists and communities are teaming up to release mosquitoes that block dengue transmission. This visual story follows the journey from lab to neighborhood, showing how R&D protects communities from disease.

item.title: Devex Newswire: Courts take their sweet time ruling on Trump's aid purge
item.description: The legal fight to preserve billions in U.S. aid. Plus, a battle rages within the U.K.’s outpost of Oxfam.

item.title: UNRWA headquarters bulldozed in East Jerusalem
item.description: The reported demolition underway early Tuesday of the headquarters of UN agency UNRWA by Israeli forces in occupied East Jerusalem - apparently “under the watch of lawmakers and a member of the Government” - has prompted swift condemnation from the global body.

item.title: Mozambique floods heighten disease, malnutrition risks – UN agencies
item.description: Catastrophic flooding across Mozambique is devastating lives and livelihoods, sharply increasing the risk of disease outbreaks and malnutrition, while also forcing dangerous wildlife – including crocodiles – into flooded urban areas, the UN warned on Tuesday.

item.title: Human trafficking depends on corruption at every step
item.description: In 2011, a trafficker in Chile was convicted for recruiting economically vulnerable Peruvian citizens and arranging for them to be brought into the country – destined to become victims of sexual exploitation.

item.title: Prison breaks and renewed clashes raise alarm in northeast Syria
item.description: The United Nations continues to monitor developments in northeast Syria following clashes between government troops and the Kurdish-led SDF militia during which scores of detained ISIL militants reportedly escaped from prison.

item.title: Cold and dark: UN rights chief condemns Russian strikes on Ukraine’s power grid
item.description: Russian attacks on Ukraine’s energy infrastructure have cut heat, electricity and water to hundreds of thousands of civilians in freezing winter conditions, prompting the UN human rights chief to denounce the strikes as “cruel” and a clear violation of international law.

item.title: At the edge of war: the Central African Republic's uneasy border with Sudan
item.description: The land flattens on the approach to Birao, a cut-off town ringed by savannah in the far north of the Central African Republic, where roads dissolve into dust and motorcycles vastly outnumber cars. Less than two hours’ drive from the Sudanese border, this is the edge of a fractured country still piecing itself back together, while absorbing the shockwaves of a neighboring conflict.

item.title: World enters era of ‘global water bankruptcy’
item.description: The world has moved beyond a water crisis and into a state of global water bankruptcy, says a new flagship report released on Tuesday by UN researchers.

item.title: The value of collaboration among public development banks
item.description: How can public development banks better work together for maximum impact? Devex sat down with the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank’s immediate past president and chair of the board of directors, Jin Liqun.

item.title: Fighting for billions: The legal battle to keep US foreign aid alive
item.description: Frozen programs, delayed payments, and billions at stake. The lawsuit that tested the limits of U.S. foreign aid continues, nearly one year after it began.

item.title: Global Survey Finds Citizens back a World Parliament as Trust in International System Erodes
item.description: As democracy faces pressure around the world and confidence in international law drops, a new global survey reveals that citizens in a vast majority of countries support the idea of creating a citizen-elected world parliament to deal with global issues. The survey, commissioned by Democracy Without Borders and conducted across 101 countries representing 90% of […]

item.title: UN Pension Review Raises Concerns Among Staff and Retirees
item.description: The United Nations General Assembly’s latest pension fund resolution — adopted at the end of December 2025 — has triggered concerns among current and former staff members of the organization that their retirement security may be at risk. The resolution invites the UN Pension Board to carry out a full review of the pension system, ... Read more

item.title: As AI rises and aid declines, can Davos shape a new compact for development?
item.description: Opinion: At Davos, governments, donors, and institutions could agree that a share of AI-driven efficiency gains in high-income settings be reinvested in frontline services and local capability in lower-income countries.

item.title: Karatoya
item.description: Once a lifeline of northern Bengal, Bangladesh’s Karatoya River now drifts through Bogura as a fragmented, polluted channel, where climate change and human neglect quietly reshape livelihoods, memory, and everyday life. Flowing through the heart of Bogura, the Karatoya River bears the weight of a long, visible decline. Once one of northern Bengal’s major […]

item.title: Money Matters: What’s in the $50 billion US aid budget?
item.description: Plus, inside the United States’ new approach to funding the U.N., Germany’s new aid plan, and a look at how the Novo Nordisk Foundation funds aid.

item.title: Which countries received the most ODA in 2024?
item.description: $163.3 billion in bilateral official development assistance was provided in 2024. Which countries received the most money? Devex crunched the numbers to find out.

item.title: Celebrated soil scientist and food security activist Pedro Sánchez dies
item.description: The food security and agricultural science communities mourn the passing of a “giant in the field,” Pedro Sánchez, who transformed farming across Africa, Asia, and Latin America.

item.title: How MCC plans to award $287.3 million in contracts in 2026
item.description: The Millennium Challenge Corporation had almost the same budget for anticipated awards as in the last fiscal year, but for a much smaller number of contracts.

item.title: Devex Newswire: What to make of development in 2026
item.description: Devex President and Editor-in-Chief Raj Kumar offers up his predictions for the year ahead.

item.title: The UN’s Withering Vine: A US Retreat from Global Governance
item.description: The Trump administration’s recent announcement of its withdrawal from 66 international organisations has been met with a mixture of alarm and applause. While the headline number suggests a dramatic retreat from the world stage, a closer look reveals a more nuanced, and perhaps more insidious, strategy. The move is less a wholesale abandonment of […]

item.title: One Carries a Broom, the Other a Schoolbag
item.description: While other children her age prepared for school, eight-year-old Tania once began her workday. Each morning, she picked up a jharu—the household broom—and cleaned floors inside a private home. At the same time, another child of her age in that household lifted a schoolbag and left for class. One carried a broom. The other carried […]

item.title: Devex Newswire: Congress speaks up about US foreign aid. Will it matter?
item.description: While the $50 billion funding bill reinstates funding for programs the administration had previously slashed, it remains uncertain whether the Trump administration will respect Congress’ authority to control government spending. Plus, preparing for development discussions in Davos.

item.title: Yemen: Children are dying and it’s going to get worse, warns aid veteran
item.description: In Yemen, renewed political instability and economic woes linked to the war threaten to complicate the already difficult task of helping vulnerable people suffering from deepening hunger, illness and displacement, the UN’s top aid official there said on Monday.

item.title: World News in Brief: Food insecurity in Lebanon, Libya migrants freed, UNHCR tackles multiple emergencies – despite cuts
item.description: Since 2026, nearly 17 percent of Lebanon’s population has been living in a state of major food insecurity – a situation that is likely to worsen in the coming year.

item.title: ‘Alarming’ increase in use of death penalty last year, despite global trend towards abolition
item.description: Despite a downward trend in the use of the death penalty globally, 2025 saw an ‘alarming’ increase in the number of executions in a small number of retentionist countries, the UN human rights office (OHCHR) warned on Monday.

item.title: Sudan: Atrocities ‘repeated town by town’, ICC prosecutor tells UN Security Council
item.description: Atrocities in Sudan’s Darfur region are spreading from town to town in an organized campaign of violence that includes mass executions, rape and ethnic targeting, amounting to war crimes and crimes against humanity, the prosecutor of the International Criminal Court told the UN Security Council on Monday.

item.title: Rising hunger and displacement pose growing economic risk, UN tells Davos
item.description: As global leaders gather at the World Economic Forum in Davos this week, UN agencies are warning that rising hunger and displacement are not only humanitarian emergencies but growing threats to global economic stability.

item.title: Davos tests the limits in a world of power, profit, and inequality
item.description: As world leaders and billionaires descend on Davos, rising inequality and collapsing multilateralism raise questions about development’s place at the World Economic Forum.

item.title: Devex Pro Insider: Power on display in Davos, but does dialogue wield any of it?
item.description: What to expect at this week's World Economic Forum in Davos. Plus, one health leader announces her bid for U.S. Congress, while another criticizes the state of Nigeria’s health system.

item.title: Can digital public infrastructure reshape donor-reliant health systems?
item.description: For years, digital health in Africa followed donor funding — often fragmented, short-term, and hard to sustain. Now, as aid contracts, countries are betting on digital public infrastructure to do things differently.

item.title: How Extreme Weather is Testing Tanzania’s $2 Billion Electric Railway Dream
item.description: Around the world, railways are considered as pillars of climate action. Electric trains produce fewer emissions than road or air transport. Yet the experience of Tanzania’s Standard Gauge Railway highlights a growing paradox: infrastructure designed to be climate-friendly is itself increasingly exposed to climate shocks.

item.title: Economic Dogma Blocks Pragmatic Policies
item.description: After condemning pragmatic responses to the 1997-98 Asian financial crises, the West pursued similar policies in response to the 2008 global financial crisis without acknowledging its own mistakes. Politicised exchange rates After US Federal Reserve Chairman Paul Volcker sharply raised interest rates from late 1979 to curb inflation, the dollar’s value strengthened despite deepening stagnation. […]

item.title: Children and Armed Conflict Must be at the Forefront of the Global Agenda
item.description: Thirty years ago, the groundbreaking report by Graça Machel, renowned and widely respected global advocate for women’s and children’s rights, to the United Nations General Assembly laid bare the devastating impact of armed conflict on children and shook the conscience of the world. It led to the historic decision of the General Assembly to create […]

item.title: Gazans Who Ended Up in South Africa Still Await Their Fate
item.description: STRUISBAAI, South Africa — Two years ago, Abdul Haddad* spent the Christmas season living in a tent on a beach in Gaza amid the horrendous conditions of the Israeli onslaught on the Palestinian territory. Like hundreds of thousands of other people there, he had lost his home in the war that Israel launched in response ... Read more

item.title: UN rights chief bears witness to trauma and resilience in Sudan
item.description: Nearly three years of war have plunged Sudan “into an abyss of unimaginable dimensions” and human rights must be at the centre of efforts to end the fighting and build lasting peace, the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights said on Sunday in Nairobi.

item.title: Will AI kickstart a new age of nuclear power?
item.description: The rapidly expanding use of artificial intelligence worldwide is putting electrical grids under huge pressure and many believe that, to meet that need without contributing to the climate crisis, a full-scale expansion of nuclear energy is essential.

item.title: Secretary-General on UN at 80: Humanity strongest when we stand as one
item.description: Powerful forces are lining up to undermine global cooperation, United Nations Secretary-General António Guterres warned at a landmark event in London on Saturday to commemorate the 80th anniversary of the General Assembly, but he urged that “humanity is strongest when we stand as one”.
